entries.title: Announcing Catalyst Community Poll and Upcoming Town Hall
entries.text: John Napiorkowski has published a 10-minute long survey about the Catalyst web framework. (It is less than 20 questions.) I don't see a dead-line so, I'd recommend you head over and fill it out ASAP, before it is closed.

entries.title: Announcing the Advanced Perl Maven e-book
entries.text: This is my second e-book. Based on the training material I am using and already including a few articles. Currently selling at 30% of its final price. It also includes a challenge to find your way how to buy it. If you get lost, let me know by e-mail, I'll help you through.

entries.title: Manage your web app with commands
entries.text: Glen Hinkle tempi.re describes how to add commands to a Mojolicious application.

entries.title: Partial parsing and error reporting using Marpa
Perl bits: Passing @_ to a subroutine
entries.text: Do you know what does &foo do? Asked and answered by Sebastian Willing

entries.title: Some lessons in optimizing Org::Parser
entries.text: What do you do if your notebook is small and slow? Steven Haryanto had to profile his perl scripts to make them run at a reasonable speed. I liked the way the story is told.

entries.title: The Lost Secret of Mug-Driven Evolution
entries.text: chromatic raised the question 'Is it reasonable to write new code in Perl right now?' and has discussed it a bit, thought the main point - something you might have heard earlier - is in the closing sentence: 'Build credible new things. Brag about them. Repeat.'. The comments section also contained a fair amount of good comments. For example the explanataion of Ovid about the Osborne effect.

entries.title: Is it reasonable to write new code in Perl right now?
entries.text: Su-Shee took the question asked by chromatic and had a longish response why she, after checking out Java, Ruby and Python, thinks Perl is still the best choice for her company.

entries.title: List of Perl modules comparison articles
entries.text: In recent years there were several articles comparing modules for specific task. Steven Haryanto created a wiki page with the hope of linking to all such comparison articles.

entries.title: Alien::Base Perl Foundation Grant Report Month 5
entries.text: Joel Berger had made some progress on the Mac front and uploaded a few modules to CPAN to be test cases for Alien::Base.

entries.title: Improving Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 10
entries.text: Nicholas Clark writes about the investigation and fix of a potential security issue in all versions of perl 5. He also explains why this is probably did not add any extra vulnerability to code pointing out other security issues a programmer could introduce by using unverified user data.

entries.title: How does interpolation of scalars, arrays and hashes work in Perl 6
entries.text: On one hand Perl 6 only interpolates scalars and not arrays, on the other hand Perl 6 has a clean syntax to interpolate the results of any expression.

entries.title: Security vulnerabilities in three commonly deployed RT extensions
Perl 5 Porters Weekly: July 16-July 22, 2012
entries.text: Perl 5.17.2 is now available; Finally there is work being done for Perl on Android!

entries.title: How to change @INC to find Perl modules in non-standard locations
entries.text: How can you use a module without installing it? Is a frequent question. In this article I gave 3 solutions for 3 different use-cases.
